sources.title: Bed and Sofa | LOVE MOVIE
sources.description:
The years of the NEP. Print worker Vladimir comes to Moscow from the province and temporarily lodges in the room of his battlefield friend Nikolai on 3rd Meshchanskaya Street. Lyudmila, the host’s wife, is fond of her guest, who, unlike her husband, is very kind to her. She makes no secret of her affection for Vladimir - and now the three of them will live together...
One of the riskiest Soviet romance films about new life. The first title of the picture is Menage a Trois. In the West, it was released as Three in a Cellar, and as Bed and Sofa in Germany. The movie was a great success but caused a string of scandals. Screenwriter Viktor Shklovsky was criticized for being disrespectful towards poet Mayakovsky and the Briks family, whom he knew well and whose love story supposedly inspired the film. The film was called immoral, and in the late 1920s it was banned. 

Year of production: 1927

Directed by: Abram Room
Written by: Viktor Shklovsky, Abram Room 
Director of photography: Gregory Giber
Production designers: Vasily Rakhals, Sergei Yutkevich
Starring: Nikolai Batalov, Lyudmila Semyonova, Vladimir Fogel

metadata.Plot: A married couple have a small apartment in Moscow. When an old friend of the husband's arrives in the city, he is unable to find lodgings. Kolia, the husband, invites his friend to move in with them. While Kolia is away on business, sensual Liuda and attractive Volodia fall in love and have an affair. After his initial outrage, the husband calms down. Kolia winds up on the sofa, and the three settle into a menage-a-trois until the wife finds herself pregnant. The two men are trying to decide what to do, but Liuda is strong enough to make her own decisions. Considered a landmark film because of humor, naturalism, and its sympathetic portrayal of the woman.
metadata.Actors: Vladimir Fogel, Nikolay Batalov, Lyudmila Semyonova
